title-group.article-title: Analytic and Continental: The Division in Philosophy

"Mind-destroying" is Passmore's expression, A Hundred Years of Philosophy, p. 477.

Carnap's "The Elimination of Metaphysics Through Logical Analysis of Language," in Logical Positivism (ed. A. J. Ayer): "That treatise [Heidegger's What Is Metaphysics?] is completely in the right in citing approvingly a statement by Hegel ('pure Being and pure Nothing, therefore, are one and the same'). The metaphysics of Hegel has exactly the same logical character as this modern system of metaphysics. And the same holds for the rest of the metaphysical systems...." (p. 73).

"Letter on Humanism," in Basic Writings of Martin Heidegger, ed. David Farrell Krell (New York: Harper and Row, 1977)
The "Letter on Humanism" began as Heidegger's reply to a letter from Jean Beaufret, the subject being Jean-Paul Sartre's Existentialism Is a Humanism (Paris: Nagel, 1946).
Paul de Man, for example, on the distinction of metaphorical (or figurai) and literal language in "Semiology and Rhetoric," Allegories of Reading (New Haven, CT. Yale University Press, 1979).
